The Ancient Magus’ Bride Complete Best, Featuring Themes and Insert Songs From the Anime and Game, Goes on Sale November 26!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • World-wide hit series The Ancient Magus’ Bride has over 12 million copies of the manga sold, two anime adaptations and numerous multi-media projects to date. The new best album featuring theme songs and insert songs from the popular series will be going on sale November 26, 2025! The CD cover for both the first edition and standard edition albums will feature special illustrations by the author Koré Yamazaki.
  • The first disc will include all of the main theme songs from both seasons such as “Here”, “Cycle”, “Nemurasareta Lineage” and more! The second disc will include popular insert songs from the anime such as “Iruna Eteluro” and “Dance of the Spirit.” Tracks such as “Quiet Choir” and “Holiday” which will be recorded on CD for the very first time on this album. The main theme song from the recently released game The Ancient Magus’ Bride: Seika no Maboroshi to Yume Miru Tabiji “Sagashimono” will be featured as well.
  • First editions will include a third disc featuring a collection of 15 tracks from the anime score selected by pianist Junichi Matsumoto, making the album a complete collection of music from the world of The Ancient Magus’ Bride.
  • Ahead of the album’s release, voices of Chise (Atsumi Tanezaki) and Elias (Ryouta Takeuchi), JUNNA and Junichi Matsumoto gave a special comment.

    • Comment From Atsumi Tanezaki (Chise V.A.)

    Congratulations on the release of the new album The Ancient Magus’ Bride Complete Best! Every song plays a crucial role in the world of The Ancient Magus’ Bride. JUNNA’s “Here” pulls on my heartstrings as it takes me back to where it all began. I still remember humming “Hana Kazoe” like a lullaby during a recording session, trying to sing like Chise. I hope everyone immerses themselves once more into this magical world through this album. I know I will be. I can’t wait for its release...!

    Comment From Ryouta Takeuchi (Elias V.A.)

    The soundtrack and music of The Ancient Magus’ Bride is so memorable, but the scene that stands out to me the most is from season 1 episode 12 when Chise finishes making her wand and returns to Elias using magic! For a scene with zero dialogue, it makes for a truly touching and beautiful scene, consisting of only the opening theme “Here” and the visuals! The music of this anime has a mysterious way of making emotions visible. I want everyone to revisit this story through this album!

    Comment From JUNNA

    Congratulations on the new album. My first single as a singer was “Here,” so The Ancient Magus’ Bride truly is a work that allowed me to grow alongside it and encounter new things. As a fan of a series that’s loved by many, and as an artist, I’m looking forward to enjoying what’s to come.

    Comment From Junichi Matsumoto

    Congratulations on the new album. It all came back to me...the scenes, the colors, the atmosphere, the air, the eyes, the expressions, the voices and the sounds... I’m happy to experience them all again through the music. I’ve carefully selected 15 tracks. I hope you enjoy this brief journey through the sounds of The Ancient Magus’ Bride.

item.title: mekakushe’s New Song “Snow Globe Galaxy” Now Streaming! Jacket Art for Upcoming Album 138-Oku Nen Me no Koi Revealed!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Singer-songwriter mekakushe has released a new song, “Snow Globe Galaxy.” This track is a pre-release from the digital album 138 Oku-nen Me no Koi, scheduled for release on November 7, 2025. Written and composed by mekakushe and arranged by Sondai Nishijima, the song is a two-step track that condenses three minutes of technical beats, as if the universe itself were trapped inside a snow globe. The jacket art and music video were created by collage artist kyabeshi.
  • The jacket art for 138 Oku-nen Me no Koi has also been revealed. It was created by Southeast Asia–based illustrator Meyoco, an Instagram influencer with over 1.17 million followers who also runs her own apparel line. In addition to the main artwork, she drew complementary illustrations, which will appear on acrylic panels distributed as special gifts for the 1st and 2nd stages of mekakushe Planetarium Acoustic Live ~138 Oku-nen Me no Koi~ on November 27.
    • https://youtu.be/pDI2RVFDg78

    Product Information

    Track Title: “Snow Globe Galaxy” Lyrics/Composition: mekakushe　 Arrangement: Sondai Nishijima Jacket Art: Kyabeshi On streaming websites: linkco.re/5TdgzZRr

    Mekakushe’s Comment

    Snow globes are beautiful and lonely, holding beginnings and endings, a fleeting eternity trapped inside. When I was little, I loved gazing at them. An infinite world fit in the palm of my hand, self-contained, compressed into a single space, and it made my heart race. Music feels the same. It ends eventually, but for a moment, it becomes my own small, enclosed world of beauty. This song is like a snow globe you can listen to, three minutes capturing beginnings and endings, beauty and loneliness, all in one.

    Sondai Nishijima’s Comment

    “Snow Globe Galaxy” is the wild card of the album, packed with surprises in its short runtime. Its signature lies in rollercoaster-like twists and technical beats. I asked Mekakushe to tackle many challenging harmonies and choruses (sorry!), and she sang beautifully, bringing to life a one-of-a-kind snow globe. Enjoy!

    Kyabeshi’s Comment

    Just like you see different scenes when you flip a snow globe, we’ve packed a variety of scenes into this music video. I’d love to hear how this video, this world, looks to you. P.S. I secretly hid seven shrimp, Mekakushe’s favorite, somewhere in the video. See if you can find them!

    Meyoco’s Comment

    It’s an honor to create an artwork for mekakushe-san’s music. I had a lot of fun creating the illustration from beginning to end. I was given the chance to create the artwork according to my style, which I deeply appreciate. The main theme I wanted to cover is a combination of “time” and “space,” with the motif of the clock being a dominant element in the artwork alongside the girl. I wanted the artworks to look warm and peaceful, the way you would feel when remembering someone you love. I hope my illustrations could serve well as a companion to mekakushe-san’s music.

    138-Oku Nen Me no Koi Tracklist

    Retronym of Love (ED theme of Kowloon Generic Romance) Zutto Emerald Kimi wa Snorkel My Own Polaris (insert song from Kowloon Generic Romance) Yuwanamerou (insert song from Kowloon Generic Romance) Sky Above Rendezvous Snow Globe Galaxy And other new songs *Tracklist subject to change. Final order and content may be updated without notice.

    Sondai Nishijima’s Profile

    Sondai Nishijima began experimenting with digital music production while at university and launched his activities as a Vocaloid producer. His work includes contributing songs to the TV anime Ore no Imouto ga Konnani Kawaii Wake ga Nai (Season 2), performing piano for The Idolmaster (Bandai Namco) songs, writing lyrics for Denenbu (Bandai Namco), providing music for Break My Case (coly), and writing columns for Singing Synthesizer Music Magazine (Stripeless Label). He has participated in a wide range of projects, both independent and commercial. He also teaches in the Arranging and Composition Department at Shobi College of Music. X: x.com/thorndique YouTube: youtube.com/@thorndique

    Kyabeshi’s Profile

    Born in Tokyo. Using a delicate and complex collage technique, they create fantastical worlds. X: x.com/kyabeshi Instagram: instagram.com/kyabeshi

    Meyoco’s Profile

    Meyoco is an illustrator and designer based in Southeast Asia. Her work is deeply influenced by comics, animation, and fashion. She’s currently focused on creating her own apparel products. Instagram: instagram.com/meyoco X: x.com/meyoco_ Bluesky: bsky.app/profile/meyoco.bsky.social

    Mekakushe’s Profile

    Handling lyrics, composition, vocals, and piano performance by herself, the next-generation singer-songwriter Mekakushe enjoys immense popularity among artists and creators. Starting classical piano at the age of three, she gradually gravitated towards pop music. Her independently produced songs were featured in a Kao Laurier commercial, and she was one of the top artists on the Spotify official playlist “Kirakira Pop Japan” with a total of 3 million plays. She is a promising emerging artist with anticipated future success. With electronica as the foundation in her recordings, her musical style continues to expand, featuring classical solos and band sets in live performances. Official YouTube channel: youtube.com/@_mekakushe_ Official X: twitter.com/_mekakushe_ Official Instagram: instagram.com/_mekakushe_ Official TikTok: tiktok.com/@_mekakushe_ Official homepage: mekakushe.com

Daoko’s New Single “Boku dake no Photon” from Her Upcoming Digital EP Now Streaming. Music Video Out Now!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Daoko released her new song “Boku dake no Photon” on September 24, 2025. This track is an advance single from her upcoming digital EP, scheduled for release on November 19, 2025.
  • The song features lyrics by Daoko, with composition and arrangement by x0o0x_ (pronounced Wakame), an up-and-coming artist with 1.22 million YouTube subscribers known for a mysterious presence and dark, atmospheric style. Together they create a unique soundscape that seems to turn fragments of the city and memory into light.
  • The jacket artwork was illustrated by Numata Zombie!?, a frequent collaborator with singers and Vocaloid producers. The psychedelic, vivid colors expand the world of the song and leave a strong impression. A music video featuring this artwork has been released on YouTube.
  • Daoko’s first Asia tour, “THE ‘YOU’ ZIZAI ASIA TOUR 2025,” wraps up with its final show at Shibuya WWW X in Tokyo on November 28. Starting in Shenzhen and traveling through Shanghai, Bangkok, Taipei, and Seoul, the tour has drawn fans across the region.
  • The tour title, combining “YOU” and “ZIZAI” (“freely”), builds on the theme of Slash-&-Burn: clearing away the old to make room for new growth. It reflects Daoko’s wish to share new musical expressions with listeners, as she continues exploring fresh creative territory with fans across Asia.

    Daoko's Profile

    Tokyo-born in 1997, Daoko rose to prominence at 15 with a song uploaded to Niconico Douga, making her major debut in 2015. Since then, she’s been active across music, anime, and commercial projects. Her hit collaboration with Kenshi Yonezu, “Uchiage Hanabi,” has surpassed 600 million views on YouTube. A multi-talented creator, Daoko has also written novels, curated live events, exhibited paintings, and acted. She founded her own agency, Tefu Tefu, in 2019. In 2023, she became the lead vocalist of the band QUBIT, and in 2024, she released her first solo album in four years, Slash-&-Burn. That same year, she was featured on Ringo Sheena’s seventh album. In 2025, Daoko has drawn further attention through her feature on Giga and TeddyLoid’s “Act,” followed by the July 23 digital release of her new single “Zense wa Busho.” A digital EP is set to follow on November 19. item.title: AVIOT Opens Pre-Orders for Ultraman Z Collaboration True Wireless Earbuds
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • AVIOT, operated by Preseed Japan Corporation, which manufactures and sells consumer electronics, has opened pre-orders for the TE-V1R-ULZ true wireless earbuds, created in collaboration with Ultraman Z. Based on the TE-V1R, this special edition features over 350 newly recorded voice lines by four members of the anti-kaiju robot force STORAGE and four Ultraman, original earbud design and packaging, and sound tuning by Masaaki Endoh.
  • From the packaging and design to the voice guidance and sound tuning, the TE-V1R-ULZ has been fully customized in tribute to Ultraman Z.
  • The earbuds and charging case feature a color scheme inspired by the STORAGE unit insignia, blending a military aesthetic with the heroic spirit of the Ultraman universe.
  • In addition to voice guidance for notifications like power and connection status, these earbuds feature a “random voice” function packed with memorable lines from the show. Altogether, 350 newly recorded voice lines are included across 14 modes, including 6 duo modes with interactions between the four STORAGE members (Haruki Natsukawa, Shota Hebikura, Yoko Nakashima, and Yuka Ohta) and the four Ultraman (Ultraman Z, Ultraman Zero, Ultraman Geed, and Ultraman Belial).
  • The special STORAGE-themed packaging includes two exclusive oversleeves showcasing all four featured Ultraman.
  • The sound tuning was supervised by Masaaki Endoh, vocalist of the opening theme “I ask that you chant my name!”

    • Product Characteristics

    Base Model The TE-V1R is the latest model in AVIOT’s popular V series, which has sold approximately 190,000 units*. The earbuds offer an ultra-long battery life of 19 hours (62 hours with the charging case) and Adaptive Hybrid Noise Canceling, which automatically adjusts the noise reduction strength based on the surrounding environment. They also feature the new Hybrid Dual Driver 2.0 for enhanced sound quality, LDAC™ support for high-resolution playback, and wireless charging functionality, making them a high-grade model that perfectly balances sound quality and functionality. *As of the end of April 2025 Special Voice Lines In addition to voice guidance for notifications like power and connection status, these earbuds feature a “random voice” function packed with memorable lines from the show. With four members of STORAGE (Haruki Natsukawa, Shota Hebikura, Yoko Nakashima, and Yuka Ohta) and four Ultraman (Ultraman Z, Ultraman Zero, Ultraman Geed, and Ultraman Belial), the earbuds offer 14 modes, including six duo modes that highlight the strength of their bonds. With over 350 voice lines, this dream collaboration of legendary heroes comes to life right in your ears. Sample voice clips will be released on the product page. Be sure to check them out! Special Design The earbuds and charging case design are inspired by the anti-kaiju robot force “STORAGE” and feature colors matching the unit insignia. While embracing a military aesthetic, the metallic gold accents evoke the Power of Light and the Rise Ultra Medals, capturing the heroic spirit of the Ultra heroes.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    Special Packaging The front and back of the package feature the STORAGE and AVIOT logos, respectively, while the inside displays portraits of the four members. Additionally, two types of oversleeves are included: one featuring Ultraman Z & Ultraman Zero, and another featuring Ultraman Geed & Ultraman Belial. It’s a thoughtfully crafted set designed to be enjoyed in three ways.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Mekakushe’s Digital Album 138-Oku Nen Me no Koi to Release on November 7! “Zutto Emerald” Available for Early Streaming Ahead of Release!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Singer-songwriter mekakushe will release her digital album 138-Oku Nen Me no Koi on November 7, 2025.
  • The album’s concept is “the universe.” Centered on tracks inspired by planets, galaxies, and cosmic imagery, it includes mekakushe’s first anime tie-in: “Retronym of Love,” the ending theme of Kowloon Generic Romance, plus insert songs “My Own Polaris” and “Yuwanamerou.” This is one of Mekakushe’s most ambitious works to date.
  • To mark her birthday on July 26, she released “Zutto Emerald” from the album for early streaming. The song blends hope and melancholy in a dreamy electro tune with a floating feel. Written and composed by mekakushe, it was arranged by Tomggg, who also worked on “Kimi wa Snorkel.” The cover art and music video were created by pixel artist Nanami Yuki.
    • youtu.be/RGaXcJgGQaM

    Product Information

    Track Title: “Zutto Emerald” Lyrics/Composition: mekakushe　 Arrangement: Tomggg Jacket Art: Yuki Nanami On streaming websites: linkco.re/29Fx4Qf6
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    138-Oku Nen Me no Koi Tracklist Retronym of Love (ED theme of Kowloon Generic Romance) Zutto Emerald Kimi wa Snorkel My Own Polaris (insert song from Kowloon Generic Romance) Yuwanamerou (insert song from Kowloon Generic Romance) Sky Above And other new songs *Tracklist subject to change. Final order and content may be updated without notice.

    Mekakushe performance at ACG Hong Kong 2025

    youtube.com/shorts/fULFKxQI3SU

    Mekakushe’s Comment

    “Love is wonderful. I’m so glad I finally realized it. Enough to wipe away everything that came before.” I’m honestly amazed that a day has come when I truly want to write lyrics full of hope like this. That’s the symbolic meaning of an emerald. The 1/f fluctuation—since water and music are alike, they’re both cold and warm at the same time. Tomggg arranged the sound to make it feel that way. It’s a secret that this song continues the story of “Kimi wa Snorkel.”

    Tomggg’s Comment

    With “Kimi wa Snorkel,” the music felt like floating and diving underwater. In this new song, “Zutto Emerald,” you can imagine happily floating and swimming around with cute floaties. I hope the music captures the feeling of a pool of happiness and the unique sparkle of emerald, expressing all kinds of light through sound.

    Yuki Nanami’s Comment

    From the moment I first heard it, images of being gently rocked by emerald water and floating softly in space came to mind, sparking a flood of ideas that made creating the illustrations very enjoyable. It’s a soft, happy song, but with a hint of sadness that makes you want to listen to it again and again. I’m very happy to be involved in the music video. It’s been a wonderful experience!

    Tomggg’s Profile

    A prolific arranger who has collaborated on projects with all kinds of artists within Japan and abroad, such as Kaho Nakamura, Chelmico, Haruno, Harmoe, Daoko, Shelheil, and Ena Mori, to name a few. His reach has since gotten even wider with the release of “Nante ne” in a recent commercial for Pokari Sweat.

    Yuki Nanami’s Profile

item.title: HypMic Movie Hits 2 Billion Yen Box Office Mark! “Claim Victory (Immersive Edition)” Exhibition Video Available for a Limited Time!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • Tokyo (November 3, 2025)- The "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle-" movie (hereafter referred to as "HypMovie") began its revival screening at 66 theaters across Japan starting September 2nd, HypMic's anniversary, to commemorate the 8th anniversary of the project's launch. With the revival, HypMovie has finally surpassed the major milestone of 2 billion yen in box office revenue.
  • HypMovie is Japan's "first" interactive movie and made its screen debut on February 21st, 2025 at 85 theaters in Japan. Due to the limited amount of interactive screening equipment, the movie continued its run at a limited number of 60 to 80 theaters in Japan. While there have been many movies in the past that started with small-scale releases of around 10 theaters, gained popularity and expanded to over 150 theaters to become major hits, HypMovie has become the first movie in Japan to surpass a box office revenue of 2 billion yen with fewer than 100 theaters from its opening day. (Source: Kogyo Tsushinsha)
  • One of the reasons the movie has been such a hit is due to its interactive nature, the first of its kind in Japan, and which plays a central role in the viewing experience. The outcome of each rap battle unfolding on the screen is decided by the audience via a specialized voting system carried out via smartphone. Viewers vote during the movie a total of 5 times to determine the winner of each battle, which means there are a total of 48 different ways the movie can play out and 7 different endings.
  • Furthermore, to commemorate the movie's success, the specially-produced video "Claim Victory (Immersive Edition)"—which is being shown at the "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle-" exhibition currently in Nagoya—has been uploaded to the official Hypnosis Mic YouTube channel for a limited time.
  • The video encapsulates the intensity of the final Division Rap Battle during the movie and is a must-see for any HypMic fan. It will only be available until September 7th 23:59 JST, so don't miss it.
  • The battle continues in theaters where HypMovie continues to be shown, and audiences in Japan have the opportunity to get their hands on some limited bonus items. As the 11th round of bonuses, “clear cards” featuring new illustrations by the Hypnosis Mic character designer Kazui will be given out to moviegoers. 2 sets of 3 designs will be randomly distributed, the first of which is Buster Bros!!!/MAD TRIGGER CREW/Fling Posse, which will be given out until September 12th, followed by the Matenro/DOTSUITARE-HOMPO/Bad Ass Temple version from September 13th until September 19th. Both are exclusive to theaters, so if you're in the area, be sure to check out the revival screenings. For theater details, check the dedicated webpage "NOVELTY" on the official HypMovie website.
  • Additionally, part of the latest round of live HypMic events featuring HypMic cast members "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle- 11th LIVE " (hereafter referred to as 11th Live), will be livestreamed in theaters in Japan alongside HypMovie. These special "Live Viewing" screenings will include a live broadcast of part of the stage performances before the movie screening, and will include the opening greeting from the cast on-stage.
  • Tickets for Fling Posse & Matenro's performance on September 6th are currently on sale. Tickets for MAD TRIGGER CREW & DOTSUITARE-HOMPO's performance on September 20th go on sale on September 13th, and tickets for Buster Bros!!! & Bad Ass Temple's October 4th performance goes on sale on September 27th. Check the official HypMovie website for information regarding participating theaters.
  • All 6 of the 11th Live performances will be livestreamed by ABEMA exclusively on their “Abema PPV” platform, with tickets currently on sale. In addition to the standard ticket which will stream footage from the main camera only, a special “multi-angle” ticket is also on sale, which allows you to freely choose between the “upper camera”, “lower camera” and “full-view camera” during the stream. PPV viewers can also enjoy special bonus content: an “I’m Home” video of the cast members recorded right after the performance, where they will talk to the camera about their thoughts and feelings directly after the show. All 6 performances can only be watched in their entirety on “Abema PPV”, so don’t miss out!

    Introduction

    Music-based character rap project Hypnosis Mic: started in September 2017 Hypnosis Mic features 18 unique characters who are divided into 6 teams: Ikebukuro Division, "Ikebukuro Division," "Yokohama Division," "Shibuya Division," "Shinjuku Division," "Osaka Division," and "Nagoya Division," where they engage in intense rap battles. Leading figures in Japan's hip hop scene are featured as creators in the tracks used for each rap battle. Each character's voice actor performs all their own songs, and so each character's story develops through the music. The world of Hypnosis Mic has been explored across a range of media, including manga, video games, stage plays, anime and more, all based on its strongly characteristic music and narrative audio dramas.

    What’s the MOVIE?

    "HYPNOSISMIC -Division Rap Battle-" is Japan's "first" audience-participation style interactive movie. The outcome of each rap battle unfolding on the screen is decided by the audience vote. Voting is conducted in real-time through the smartphone app "CtrlMovie" system by Kino Industries, and the story progresses based on the outcome of these votes. The movie’s story and ending shift with each screening depending on the choices of each audience member, making each screening unique... The first-ever interactive movie experience in the history of Japanese cinema. item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • The popular adventure game Hito no Calendar came to an end Sunday, August 31. Following the conclusion of the game, multi-talented singer, voice actress, and actress Nonoka Obuchi released the game’s theme song “Hachigatsu no Afterglow” as her new digital single at midnight on September 1.
  • Hito no Calendar is the latest installment in the Hito no Wallet series by D4KK(Daiyonkyokai), a group of creators that weave stories in the space between reality and virtuality. It went on sale on the official online shop in May.
  • The game is described as “a web-based adventure game that begins with a young girl’s calendar.” The story would develop in real time until Sunday, August 31 when it reached its ending. The ending theme song was revealed at that moment as Nonoka Obuchi’s “Hachigatsu no Afterglow.”
  • In tandem with the game’s conclusion, “Hachigatsu no Afterglow” was promptly released as a digital single at midnight Monday, September 1. The single marks her very first grand ballad, featuring emotional vocals and the sound of live instruments that bring the scenes to life in a way that will leave a lasting impression on listeners.
  • A digital jacket design was released alongside the single featuring an illustration that was used in the game. Listeners can check out the design on the official audio.

  • Singer-songwriter majiko, who has garnered over 200 million streams across Asia and more than 580,000 YouTube subscribers, released her new song “Nande?” on August 22. This follows the release of “NA TTE NAI” on July 18. Both tracks will be part of her upcoming digital EP GOLDEN JUNKIE, set to release on October 17.
  • Written, composed, and arranged entirely by majiko, “Nande?” marks a shift from the beat-driven style of “NA TTE NAI,” featuring primarily live instruments. A catchy pop tune, it is anchored by the repeated chorus phrase “Nande?” (“Why?”). The music video, illustrated by Messy Nyasuppeno—who also created the visuals for “Teddy”—was released on the same day as the song.

    • Release Information

    majiko's Profile

This upbeat pop song with a Japanese twist that stays true to the lively and unique world of Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi, where supernatural beings and humans dwell together and explore themes such as “connection” and “belonging.” On the other hand, the ending theme song explores the main character, Aoi Tsubaki’s feelings towards her Odanna in a warm and heartfelt ballad by Tota Kasamura (LIVE LAB).
  • Additionally, a new photo of Nao Toyama pays homage to the original photo used during the initial announcement of Toyama’s tie-in with the anime seven years ago. While the photo evokes memories of the past, Nao appears to embody “maturity” and “change.”
  • Limited first edition copies of the single will include select recordings from Nao Toyama’s solo live concert “Watashi no Kangaeta Muteki na Setlist!” on Blu-Ray. These valuable recordings were chosen by Nao Toyama herself for the single. The limited anime edition will include an original illustrated CD cover and a special variety program “Nao’s Kitchen” featuring Nao Toyama recreating the dishes served in Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi: Ni as well.

item.title: [리뷰] 스위치 2로 등장한 더 강력한 콤비 액션의 재미 ‘이스 X –프라우드 노딕스-’
[리뷰] 발렛(VARLET), 페르소나의 향기가 조금 나는 RPG
Anime NYC 2025 - Post-Show Field Report
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Anime NYC 2025 has come and gone so quickly! Every year, we have to wait till Anime NYC arrives again and begin to prepare. We grab our notepads, think about how to tackle all that’s within the convention halls, and ready our wallets to be emptied by the merchandise we’ll buy and the food we’ll devour! It’s hard not to feel like, when this convention finally starts, it’s over in the blink of an eye... That being said, we attended 4 days of Anime NYC 2025 and had quite a few experiences, some good and others bad, and that’s why we once more present to you all our post-show field report to entertain you! Read all about our various trials and tribulations, as well as some of the shining moments of this year’s Anime NYC! Now, let’s relive Anime NYC 2025!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

While the prices have risen pretty dramatically, Anime NYC 2025 was larger than previous years and had a lot more events and big name guests. The prices might be a bit hard to stomach for some but again, it was kind of unavoidable.

Company/Event Message for Fans/Attendees

“Anime NYC is a creation of LeftField Media, an event company made of dedicated fans and convention organizers. Anime NYC is built with tremendous support from Crunchyroll and publishers across the Japanese pop culture industry.”

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

What Anime NYC 2025 Did Better Than Before

In comparison to 2024, Anime NYC 2025 had a lot more to explore. There were plenty of booths, from VTUBERS such as Hololive, where fans of various VTUBERs could join together, sing with them, listen to their randomness, and just enjoy a dedicated gaming hall where various tournaments were being held, like Tekken 8, Street Fighter 6, and even Super Smash Bros! Famous YouTubers like IronMouse and CDAWG VA were there too (sadly, we couldn’t watch them due to time constraints), and that was pretty neat! There were also a slew of popular voice actors out there for meetups, interviews, and fan questions. Needless to say, this Anime NYC was without a doubt the most varied one to date. Regardless of what type of otaku you are, Anime NYC 2025 had you covered! There were plenty of booths this year, ensuring a bit more variety than past outings. There was the Hololive stage, where fans of various VTUBERs could join their favorites, sing with them—they performed numerous anime and popular English songs—listen to them talk about silly topics, and even join in as if they were part of the group! Almost every day, Hololive was the loudest event by far, showing just how passionate those fans are. Those who wanted a more typical anime con affair could scour the floors for merchandise from numerous vendors, like Yen Press, Good Smile Company, Viz Media, and plenty of others. But with how pricey Anime NYC 2025 was, this certainly would stretch your savings a bit. We’d be lying if we didn’t admit we got a ton of figures ourselves, but it was well worth it to show our support to our favorite vendors. Gaming otaku weren’t left in the dark at Anime NYC 2025! There was a big emphasis on games this year, with an entire floor dedicated to hosting gaming events. Con-goers could play against others in their favorite fighting games like Tekken 8, Street Fighter 6, and even Super Smash Bros! There were also card game tables for all the favorites, like Magic the Gathering, Yu-Gi-Oh, and so on. We even heard that some popular YouTubers like IronMouse and CDawgVA were playing games with the crowd! Due to time constraints, we couldn’t see them ourselves, but from the fan roars, we know they were enjoying the event! Lastly, there were quite a few panels and voice actor meetups available! Famous voice talent like Kaiji Tang, Christopher Sabat, Aleks Le, AMALEE, and others were there to talk to con-goers, sign merch, or take photos! There were also plenty of panels where con-goers could learn more about numerous industry themes and/or upcoming projects. It would be impossible to see and experience everything in one day, let alone four, but at the very least, you couldn’t say there was nothing to do at Anime NYC 2025!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

What Anime NYC 2025 Could Have Done Slightly Better

Unfortunately, Anime NYC 2025 wasn’t without its drawbacks. The first—and most glaring—was overcrowding. We here at Honey’s Anime have been to our fair share of conventions, large and small, and Anime NYC 2025 is a medium-sized one compared to the titan that is Anime Expo. Nevertheless, it was clear that there was either no limit on how many could attend or a false expectation of how many would show up. Lines affected almost everything at the con, from food stalls and vendors to meeting some of the guests. The lines for food stalls were so long at times that they spilled into the non-food vendor areas, which was just terrible. Equally, seeing some of the guests was a nightmare, as lines could go on so long that it would be either impossible to meet them—unless you were there early enough—or by the time you worked your way up to the guest, they were on break or done with their time slot. Seriously, Anime NYC 2026 needs to consider capping ticket amounts or opening more of the Javits Center so there’s more room. Another issue was the lack of big gaming vendors. Despite scouring the floor, we really only saw a few minor ones. Don’t get us wrong—we were more than thrilled to see Honor of Kings with their Detective Conan collaboration and Kaiju No.8, which we could play briefly—it looks and plays incredibly well for a mobile/Steam game. Yet, we were expecting some bigger gaming panels, maybe from Capcom or even SEGA. We get that this is an anime convention, but it does have a lot of gamers who attend, and we would have liked some more gaming content.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Cosplay Was Amazing, Once Again

As you can see, there was a lot of cosplay, but we always try to look for the more unique ones. In our gallery, there are the usual cosplayers, but we are very happy to include some funny and stylish ones from Anime NYC 2025! All cosplayers who had individual photos taken were asked for permission beforehand, so thank you all for posing for Honey’s Anime! Hopefully next year we’ll see even more from newer anime airing!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Anime NYC 2025 was great despite some issues here and there. In our opinion, more people attending shows a greater appreciation for the convention, which is wonderful—but it also means that more of the Javits Center should be opened to help remedy the crowd. All things considered, we had a great time and would love to thank Anime NYC 2025 for allowing us the privilege to attend as press once again! We hope to see you all at Anime NYC 2026, which will no doubt happen after the success of this year! For now, though, we’re going to rest our tired wings and take a much-deserved nap… [author author_id="078" author="" translator_id=""] [ad_bottom class="mt40"]

  • qdopp Inc., the operator of the global novel submission platform Honeyfeed, is pleased to announce that the popular web novel Why Kill? When Witches Can Be Tentacled! by author kazesenken is now officially in development for potential publication in Japan by KADOKAWA CORPORATION.
  • The story gained significant attention within the Honeyfeed community and was eventually picked up by KADOKAWA MF BOOKS. As a result, the project was approved internally to move forward under the Global UGC Publishing Project, part of KADOKAWA’s Global Business Acceleration Program. This initiative aims to discover promising international writers through overseas novel platforms like Honeyfeed.
  • “This announcement marks a new milestone in our mission to connect international authors with Japanese publishers,” said Manami Fukunaga, Manager of The Hivemind Literary Agency, a division of qdopp Inc. that represents select Honeyfeed authors. “We’re excited to see kazesenken’s talent formally recognized and supported within the Japanese publishing industry.”
  • Further details such as final publication approval, release date, and format will be shared in due course. For now, fans can celebrate the exciting news that Why Kill? is officially in the pipeline for future print development.

    Misunderstandings - created at a glance, but difficult to get rid of. Two people are caught in the midst of them, fighting to find a place for themselves. For Maribell Schuzen, stumbling upon the Grimoire of Lies meant being labeled as a Witch, a follower of the slain Demon Lord and enemy of the entire world. For Snazzy-chan, a popular streamer and otaku extraordinaire, a new fate has him wrapped up with tentacles. Tentacles, you say? Why, Snazzy is now a jellyfish of all things! “But don’t worry, Snazzy is a gentlemanly jellyfish!” Swearing to protect Maribell with all that his little body can do, Snazzy will show the world that keeping a Witch wrapped up is preferable to a dead Witch! item.title: Main Visual and Promotional Video Out Now! Exclusive Worldwide Streaming on Prime Video Begins October 4!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • SANDA, by Paru Itagaki (creator of BEASTARS), is an unconventional Santa Claus action series set in near-future Japan, where extreme measures are taken to protect children amid a sharp population decline. The anime premieres in Japan on October 3, 2025, with exclusive worldwide streaming on Prime Video beginning October 4 at 2:53 a.m.
  • Today, the main visual and full promotional video were released. The main visual depicts Daikoku Welfare Academy, where protagonist Sanda and his classmates study, with school principal Hifumi Oshibu—who exerts extreme control over the children—looming in the background. Santa Claus dramatically bursts through glass, symbolizing hope in a bleak future.
  • The reveal also introduces key characters and cast: Toshihiko Seki voices 92-year-old principal Oshibu, who obsessively clings to youth through repeated full-body plastic surgery, and Hiroaki Hirata plays Saburo Yagiuda, ace of the St. Nick Pursuit Unit dedicated to capturing Santa. Comments from both voice actors are included below.
  • The promotional video, showcasing Science SARU’s dynamic animation, portrays a world where children are tightly controlled and Santa is freed from a curse through wishes. It also features the first voice lines from the newly revealed characters Oshibu and Yagiuda.
  • The opening and ending themes have also been announced. The opening theme, “Childlike Adults,” is by yama, and the ending theme, “Diary,” is by Soushi Sakiyama. Comments from both artists are included below.
  • https://youtu.be/PG9F1afLT-Y

    New Characters and Voice Cast Revealed, with Comments!

    Hifumi Oshibu (Voiced by Toshihiko Seki)

    The 92-year-old principal of Daikoku Welfare Academy, where Sanda and his classmates study. Obsessed with youth, he repeatedly undergoes full-body plastic surgery. He has an extreme dislike of adults and goes to abnormal lengths to protect and monitor his students’ every move. Comment 1. How did you feel when you were cast as Oshibu in SANDA? And what message do you have for fans looking forward to the series? Of all Paru Itagaki’s works, SANDA was one I was especially interested in. And among her many characters, Hifumi Oshibu’s personality stands out. I approached the role with a fresh mindset to fully capture his unique presence. Please look forward to it! 2. Since this is an action series featuring Santa Claus, is there anything you’d want to ask him for? If Santa Claus were like the one in this series, every Christmas would be far more exciting! But if a real Santa Claus existed, I think I’d ask him to promise a future where children everywhere can live in safety. Profile Born: Tochigi Prefecture Major roles: Muzan Kibutsuji in Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba, Medama Oyaji in Birth of Kitaro: The Mystery of GeGeGe, and Hansuke Doi in Nintama Rantaro

    Saburo Yagiuda (Voiced by Hiroaki Hirata)

    The ace of the St. Nick Pursuit Unit dedicated to capturing Santa. Twenty years ago, he inflicted a serious injury on Santa Claus. Comment 1. How did you feel when you were cast as Yagiuda in SANDA? And what message do you have for fans looking forward to the series? Although my character only appears partway through the story, I was warmly welcomed and had a great time recording. These days, there aren’t many productions where we go out drinking after recording, but with this one, everyone’s a heavy drinker, and I got dragged out until late at night every time. I’m counting on you, Murase! 2. Since this is an action series featuring Santa Claus, is there anything you’d want to ask him for? Although I’m over 60, I’m still full of worldly desires. I think I’d ask Santa to help me become the kind of person who can say, “I have nothing more to wish for.” Profile Born: August 7, 1963, Tokyo Major roles: Sanji in ONE PIECE, Sha Gojyo in Saiyuki, and Beryl Gardenant in From Old Country Bumpkin to Master Swordsman

    Opening Theme Song

    “Childlike Adults” by yama (Sony Music Labels Inc.)

    Comment from yama

    　　　 What does it mean to be an adult? Simply growing older does not necessarily make you one. Likewise, I do not believe that being young automatically makes someone a child. Silently carrying pain is both weakness and fragility, and facing it alone might be a clumsy way of avoiding reality. I once thought there was virtue in growing older while holding onto that fragility. But in recent years, whether with people close to me or through music, I have gradually begun to open my heart. The line between myself and others has not changed, yet through connecting with others I discover new sides of myself. I do not think of myself as either an adult or a child, but rather believe that people possess both qualities at any age. It is not about clinging to one side or deciding what is right or wrong. I have simply realized that I want to trust someone, and that is also a way of trusting myself. To anyone else who feels caught between the two, I hope this reaches you.

    Ending Theme Song

    “Diary” by Soushi Sakiyama (Sony Music Labels Inc.)

    Comment from Soushi Sakiyama

    I’m honored to perform the ending theme. I felt a deep connection to Kazushige’s inner struggle, caught between adulthood and childhood, and I poured those emotions into the song. In a world without clear answers, where each person’s idea of justice collides, the way Kazushige moves forward with so many voices in his heart has moved me time and again. I hope you enjoy the song together with the anime.

    TV Anime SANDA Overview

    Broadcast begins October 3, 2025 in Japan Official X (formerly Twitter): x.com/sanda_anime Official website: sanda.red

    Cast

    Kazushige Sanda: Ayumu Murase Santa Claus: Hiroki Touchi Shiori Fuyumura: Umeka Shoji Ichie Ono: Anna Nagase Hitoshi Amaya: Yuuki Shin Nico Kazao: Misato Matsuoka Hifumi Oshibu: Toshihiko Seki Saburo Yagiuda: Hiroaki Hirata

    Staff

    Original: “SANDA” by Paru Itagaki (Akita Shoten / Shonen Champion Comics) Director: Tomohisa Shimoyama Script: Kimiko Ueno Music: Tomoyuki Tanaka (FPM) Character Design & Chief Animation Director: Masamichi Ishiyama Art Director: Miki Higaki Color Design: Saori Goda Compositing Director: Hikari Itoh Editor: Kiyoshi Hirose Sound Director: Keiichiro Miyoshi Animation Production: Science SARU Opening Theme song: “Childlike Adults” by yama Ending Thema song: “Diary” by Soushi Sakiyama

    Original Manga

    Volumes 1 through 16 of Paru Itagaki’s SANDA (published by Akita Shoten under the Shonen Champion Comics label) are now on sale!

item.title: Opening Theme Song for Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi: Ni is Masayoshi Oishi’s “Tooryanse” sung by Nao Toyama!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • The new opening theme song for TV anime Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi: Ni “Tooryanse” by voice actress and singer Nao Toyama will be released November 5, 2025. The song was written and composed by hit-maker Masayoshi Oishi. This upbeat pop song with a Japanese twist that stays true to the lively and unique world of Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi, where supernatural beings and humans dwell together and explore themes such as “connection” and “belonging.”
  • Limited first edition copies of the single will include select recordings from Nao Toyama’s solo live concert “Watashi no Kangaeta Muteki na Setlist!” These valuable recordings were chosen by Nao Toyama herself for the single. The limited anime edition will include an original illustrated CD cover and a special variety program featuring Nao Toyama recreating the dishes served in Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi: Ni as well. Don’t miss out on this charming opening theme song and gorgeous single!

    • Nao Toyama’s Comment

    It was my pleasure to sing the theme song “Tooryanse” for the sequel of Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi. Thank you! Seven years ago, “Tomoshibi no Manimani” became one of my signature songs and a frequent number during my live concerts, still loved by fans until this day. Masayoshi Oishi’s killer track “Tooryanse” captures the bizarre and lively feeling of living alongside demons in the world of Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi. I hope that this song will become a treasure that everyone can treasure together! Please enjoy!

    Masayoshi Oishi’s Comment

    I had the pleasure of writing and composing the opening theme song “Tooryanse!” I had always wanted to write a song for Nao Toyama and for a popular series like Kakuriyo no Yadomeshi, so I was incredibly happy when I was approached for this song! I wanted to create something lively with a distinct Japanese sound that was powerful and exotic. I hope this track brings a little something extra to the work!

    Release Information

    November 5, 2025 Limited First Edition: VTZL-257 CD and Blu-ray: 3,740 yen (tax incl.) Limited Anime Edition: VTZL-258 CD and DVD: 2,860 yen (tax incl.) Standard Edition: VTCL-35388 CD only: 1,540 (tax incl.)

    Streaming Information

    jvcmusic.lnk.to/toyamanao Available on select music streaming services and major music download platforms such as iTunes Store, Rekochoku and mora. Streaming services: Apple Music, Spotify, YouTube Music, LINE MUSIC, Amazon Music, Deezer, AWA, Rakuten Music, KKBOX

    Nao Toyama's Profile

    Birthday: March 11 Blood Type: A Hometown: Tokyo Hobbies: Singing, dancing, playing the electric organ Nao Toyama made her voice acting debut in 2010. She attracted a lot of attention for her role as Kanon Nakagawa in the TV anime The World God Only Knows. After that, she went on to play characters in numerous popular works, such as Karen Kujo in Kin-iro Mosaic, Chitoge Kirisaki in Nisekoi, Reina Prowler in MacrossΔ, and Rin Shima in Yuru CampΔ. She also belongs to popular groups Rhodanthe* and Walküre, both of which were born in anime, and has enthralled fans with her clear voice and flawless performances. On February 1, 2017, she made her debut as a singer with “True Destiny/Chain the world,” tie-up songs for the anime Chain Chronicle: Haecceitas no Hikari, and on February 3, 2018, she held her first solo live at the Nippon Budokan. In 2019, she held her first solo tour and performed overseas in Taipei and Shanghai. In 2020, she celebrated her 10th anniversary as a voice actress by releasing her character song best album “Special Thanks” and holding a 10th anniversary concert titled “Special Thanks! Festival” at Tokyo Garden Theater. In 2022, she celebrated the 5th anniversary of her singing debut with five projects. On February 22, 2025, she held her solo live concert “Watashi no Kangaeta Muteki na Setlist!”

    Masayoshi Oishi's Profile

    Born in 1980 in Uwajima city, Ehime Prefecture. Singer, songwriter, musician. Debuted in 2001 with the three-man band Sound Schedule which he formed while in university. In 2008, he made his solo debut under the name Masayoshi Oishi. His unique style of storytelling while playing guitar and impressive fingering technique has become a topic of interest on YouTube and has captured the attention of younger generations. In 2014, he began creating anime and gaming content. In 2017, his track “Welcome to Japari Park” the opening theme song for Kemono Friends became a huge hit. He’s worked on numerous popular anime series, formed the musical unit OxT with Tom-H@ck, and created songs for various artists under different names.

item.title: BEYBLADE X US National Tournament Brings Anime-Worthy Duels to Los Angeles Anime Expo 2025
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

TAKARATOMY held its first-ever Beyblade X National U.S. Open-Class Qualifier as part of their BEYBLADE X World Championship 2025, hosted inside the Los Angeles Anime Expo ― marking 25 years since the brand first arrived in the U.S.! If that’s not hinting at how exhilarating this contest was, keep on reading!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

A surge of excitement radiated through the Entertainment Hall, and for those attendees who visited, it was common to hear the thrilling chant of “3… 2… 1… Let it RIP!!” echoing through the venue. It was an instant attention-grabber for fans young and old who had ever watched the anime or played Beyblade themselves. Impossible to miss, the Beyblade championship arena drew in thousands of spectators over the four days of the convention. On Saturday, July 5, the tournament reached its final stage, attracting 128 competitors who made history by participating in the first official U.S. Open-Class single-elimination showdown.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Not only did contestants experience the structure of an official tournament, like those held in Japan, but this was also foreshadowing, as the champion of the U.S. tournament would advance to the Beyblade X World Championship 2025 in Japan, with an all-expenses-paid trip to represent the United States. Honey’s Anime had the opportunity to sit front row for the final showdown, and trust us when we say the crowd was filled with extreme positivity, immaculate energy, and a raging hype that built up even more each round.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Starting with the third-place match, TMS faced Cosmo Dragon, a duel that TMS slayed with a 3-point victory, a survivor finish!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Next up was Yushwa, cosplaying as Takao Kinomiya, the protagonist of “Bakuten Shoot Beyblade,”the first series of the Beyblade anime. His opponent was ElenaBEY, a woman who won the hearts of the crowd thanks to her meme-worthy championship picture. Despite their playful demeanor, the two finalists delivered a seriously intense battle that was just as exciting as duels we’ve seen in the anime!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

This battle was truly worthy of being the last match in the national US championship, it had it all. Mid-air collision, survivor finish, and a double knockout finish you name it! This battle was intense. In the end, ElenaBEY’s trusty Dran Buster 5-60 LF pulled through, helping her make a comeback after a draw and score two points with a knockout to win the championship.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The Entertainment Hall erupted with intense cheering for ElenaBEY, who secured her ticket to Tokyo this October for the global finals. But she wasn’t the only one being celebrated. The crowd was going wild for all eight top competitors who delivered thrilling action throughout the day. We had the opportunity to do a quick interview with the top 3, and this is what they had to say:

Interview with TMS, 3rd Place

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: Did you come today with the intention of winning, or just having fun? Did you expect to make it this far? A: I came all the way from Texas to win. I was waiting since 2018 for this moment and the experience was insane; I’m just really happy to get to compete. Q: How did you hear about this tournament at AX, and was this your first time in a tournament? A: I’m a content creator who focuses on competitive Beyblade so of course I knew about this and I’ve been in 32 tournaments just in the past 6 months to make it here. Q: After today’s defeat, do you plan on changing your strategy? A: I plan to constantly change my style as always, trying out different styles of my interest.

Interview with Yushwa, 2nd Place

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: After such an intense spin-off against ElenaBEY, how do you feel? A: Exhausted! And stressed, but I wanted to make sure people had a good time watching the match. Q: We’ve noticed you have quite a fan following among the crowd. Do you have a few words to share with your fans? A: SoCal is still strong. We need more tournaments, more opportunities to give a chance to more players. Don’t stop playing until Beyblade becomes an e-sport! Until then, we need to take care of each other. I hope everyone had fun watching my matches and that I could deliver what the crowd wanted to see.

Interview with ElenaBEY, US Champion

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
Q: In a competitive scene like Beyblade X, how do you feel as a woman having won this championship in a game predominantly played by men? A: Now I feel proud to represent women in Beyblade, not only as the U.S. champion. I want to show that Beyblade is for everyone, and I hope my win influences more women to join the world of Bey. Q: Did you come to this tournament focused on winning? A: I never expected to reach the top, or win! My friends helped me out with the knowledge of what Beyblade to pick, they helped me a lot through the preliminaries so I feel this win is for everyone who helped me. I am surprised I won! Q: Were you surprised that the champion would have a chance to trip to Japan to join the BEYBLADE X World Championship 2025? Is this your first time going? A: No, it wasn’t a surprise. People were talking about the chance to compete in the World Championship in Japan. It’s not my first time in Japan, but I’m really looking forward to the shopping and food in Tokyo! Q: Any final words for your fans? A: The most important thing is to have fun and keep playing!
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The Beyblade X National Tournament not only made history in the U.S but also delivered an unforgettable experience to fans and players alike. Tokyo, get ready—passion is on its way from the U.S.

item.title: [Honey's Anime Interview] Goro Taniguchi, Creative Producer for "Enter the Garden", an Anime Series by Azuki and Dentsu
item.content:encoded:
At Anime Expo 2025, Honey’s Anime sat down with famous director Goro Taniguchi, best known for Code Geass, to talk about his latest experimental work as the creative producer for Enter the Garden, an original anime produced by Azuki in collaboration with Dentsu. Known for its unique blend of American streetwear aesthetics and traditional Japanese visuals, Enter the Garden marks a bold departure from Japan’s traditional anime production model. Taniguchi shared his thoughts on creative freedom, artistic philosophy, and how Azuki’s community is reshaping what it means to create anime.

Goro Taniguchi
Honey-Chan
Interview with Goro Taniguchi
[gray-hex-decoration]
You've worked within the traditional Japanese pipeline of transforming an idea into anime. How has your experience differed working with Azuki, especially given their focus on short-format anime and changing how anime is produced?
In the past, I usually worked with stories that already existed. This time working with Azuki, there was no original material to reference. So the process started with me asking, “Is this the right path?” and then presenting my ideas to Azuki. Sometimes those ideas were rejected, but the key has been constant communication between us. I’ve had to understand Azuki’s goals and translate that into animation. This open, cross-partner dialogue is very different from working with Japanese publishers or studios that produce anime, manga, or light novels in a traditional format. So far, it’s been a refreshing and exciting change for me.
Enter the Garden seems to be inspired heavily by modern American street fashion and traditional Japanese elements. Could you tell me more about what inspired the look and aesthetic of the world?
As I mentioned earlier, we first asked the Azuki side to show us what kind of things they were thinking about and wanted to do, as well as what kinds of fan art existed. From there, we picked out the parts of their ideas that we understood or that we also thought were cool. Staff members who understood the concept arranged everything in the form of Episode 1, Episode 2, and Episode 3.
Are there plans to introduce other cultural aspects from different countries in future episodes?
That’s something I intentionally avoid. Digging deeper into the reasoning, the staff working on the project had already had that kind of idea in the past; however, we have agreed on focusing on one style identity with room for subtle influences. If I direct that they should include other cultural references, it may hinder the staff’s creativity. That’s something I would like to avoid. I believe that giving the team creative freedom yields better results. I purposely place staff who can generate something good without being influenced. To give more details, for episode 1, I assigned staff who had worked on things other than anime. In episode 2, I assigned staff who could also illustrate the 1980s to 2000s era’s anime style. By doing this, I can ensure each episode has its own uniqueness.
What can you tell me about the character’s personality? Are they in any way influenced by Azuki’s company philosophy or your vision as a director?
As for episode 1, the world setting is Azuki’s idea but the characters were created under our direction. In episode 2, we featured Azuki’s original characters, but I directed how they came to life on screen. Episode 3, which hasn’t been released yet, both the characters and the world were created as a way to further expand our interpretation of Azuki.
When you talk about expanding in artwork and animation technique, in what way do you mean exactly? Are you talking about introducing techniques like rotoscopying or stop motion animation?
It’s not about technique for the sake of technique. It’s about philosophy and how to express an idea visually. If stop motion helps convey that concept, we’ll use it. But technique is secondary to intention. What matters most is expressing the underlying message in a compelling way.
Between episodes 1 and 2 of Enter the Garden, there seems to have been some evolution regarding animation. How did Azuki grow during this process, and what did you learn?
Absolutely, there’s been growth. Originally, I had my plans for episodes 2 and 3. But after finishing episode 1, Azuki suggested new ideas for episode 2, probably ideas that reflected community feedback. I didn’t see these suggestions as just coming from a company, but as a petition from the fans. So I made adjustments to my original vision. Anime is a business, yes, but it’s also for the fans. Their input helped shape the direction of the project.
What message or experience do you hope to deliver to the anime community with Enter the Garden?
Whatever message I want to convey can only be delivered through the anime itself. That’s why I create. What makes this project special is that it listens to the fans and translates their voice into animation. That’s what truly matters.
Are you hoping to bring more creators into the Azuki community, or is this anime laying the groundwork for something bigger?
Whether it's from the wide anime community or Azuki’s community, if you are a creator, the more eyes on your work, the better. My goal isn’t just to cater to the Azuki community, it’s to reach the wider anime audience. By doing this, if that draws more people into Azuki, that’s something I can feel happy about. If that happens, you can say creating Enter the Garden anime was successful.
Working with legends like Tatsuyuki Tanaka on Enter the Garden must be a unique experience. How do you foster an equal creative environment for industry veterans?
The answer is very simple. As the director, I define clear creative boundaries. I explained the project and everyone’s responsibilities at the start. Mr. Tanaka understood exactly what his role was and where his creative domain lay. Once that’s clear, I don’t interfere unless someone steps outside their zone. That mutual respect is what keeps the environment clear of issues.
Goro Taniguchi’s approach to Enter the Garden reveals a balance between personal creative vision and open collaboration with both Azuki and its growing community. This experimental project isn’t just about breaking anime conventions in format and production, it’s about exploring how far you can go when fan voices, corporate goals, and experienced direction meet halfway. With more episodes on the horizon and an evolving aesthetic, Enter the Garden may just be a blueprint for a new era of anime production where creators like Taniguchi continue to innovate beyond borders.

item.title: [사일런트힐 F] 60년대 일본 문화와 뒤섞인 SH식 기괴함.. '아름답기 때문에 역겨웠다'
[Honey's Anime Interview] Takayuki Miyauchi and Kenta Wakisawa From T-SPARK at the Los Angeles Anime Expo 2025
item.content:encoded:
At Anime Expo 2025 in Los Angeles, Honey’s Anime had the opportunity to sit down with two key figures driving strategy and innovation in the world of collectible figures and character goods: Takayuki Miyauchi (Senior Assistant Manager of the Marketing Team in the Collector Business Group, Hobby Character Business Division) and Kenta Wakisawa (Assistant Manager of the R&D Team in the same division). In our conversation, Miyauchi-san and Wakisawa-san offered a rare glimpse into the heart of the industry—and how they plan to keep surprising collectors worldwide.

Miyauchi
Wakisawa
Honey-Chan
Interview with the T-SPARK Team
[gray-hex-decoration]
T-SPARK is described as a brand for adult hobbyists. What’s the vision behind creating a unified brand for adult hobbyists and has that vision evolved since its launch?
Wakisawa: Our division handles long-running IPs like Transformers and ZOIDS, and we’d already been developing products for a high-target demographic. So under the company-wide policy of increasing lifetime value and expanding customer segments, we decided to take the lead in expanding offerings for kidults (adults with a playful spirit). Although the toy and hobby businesses may seem similar, their structures differ significantly. So for this initiative, we assembled a project team that included members beyond just management and our division. Together, we held in-depth discussions, looking ten years ahead, on how our company should approach and expand the kidult market from a medium- to long-term perspective. Through those discussions, we realized that Takara TOMY now targets a wide spectrum of customers, from children to adults, and that this requires different approaches for each segment in both product development and marketing. In the hobby category especially, we recognized the need to clearly define and separate our kidult offerings. For instance, our official YouTube channel previously featured videos for both kids and adults, but to deliver more relevant content to each audience, shouldn’t we consider separating the channels? There are also differences in focus between children’s and adults’ products when it comes to quality and ethical standards, raising the need for distinct criteria. As we looked to expand the kidult segment over the medium to long term, it became clear that clearer boundaries were needed. That led to the decision to launch a separate label for kidult-focused collector items. This was the rationale behind T-SPARK, and our vision has remained unchanged since its launch.
How do you prepare your marketing strategies to reach its intended audience, particularly in international markets like here in the USA?
Wakisawa: We only began expanding into the U.S. market in 2025, so we’re still in the early stages, testing various strategies to see what works. While overall trends in the U.S. market aren’t drastically different from those in Japan, action figures are a particularly strong category, and in recent years, Japanese IPs have become extremely popular. By leveraging that interest in Japanese culture and applying Takara TOMY’s hobby expertise, we aim to develop new products and build awareness of the T-SPARK brand. Our appearance at AX this time is part of that effort. Looking ahead, we plan to roll out a variety of collaboration products featuring popular manga, anime, and other globally loved content. We’re also working to strengthen our online presence, centered around our North American e-commerce platform, Tommy Plus. At the same time, we want to create more offline touchpoints, such as places where fans can see product samples in person.
How do you approach targeting adult collectors over younger fans, especially when working with huge titles like My Hero Academia that attract multi-generational audiences?
Miyauchi: We believe that expanding the T-SPARK brand is essential to gaining traction with adult collectors. The new figure brands we’ve launched will offer a wide range of products, from affordable to high-end, designed to appeal to various fan demographics. SPARK Fig is a mid- to high-priced series targeting adult collectors, while the COLLEKAZARO series is designed not only for adult collectors but also to appeal to female fans. By offering a diverse range of products targeting a broad fan base, we hope to raise awareness of the T-SPARK brand among as many people as possible.
Although brief, our conversation with Miyauchi-san and Wakisawa-san shed light on how Takara TOMY is shaping the future of its collector business through T-SPARK, a brand built with a playful spirit, yet crafted with the sophistication and quality adult fans expect. From the long-term vision that led to creating a distinct label, to early steps in expanding into the U.S. market, and the thoughtful strategies behind engaging multi-generational fandoms with lines like SPARK Fig and COLLEKAZARO, it’s clear that T-SPARK represents more than just figures—it’s a commitment to redefining what it means to collect, connect, and celebrate Japanese pop culture on a global scale.

Written by Daoko and composed/arranged by Seiichi Nagai of QUBIT—where she also serves as lead vocalist—the track blends Nagai’s signature guitar work with Daoko’s playful voice and sharp wordplay. The tour finale is scheduled for November 28 at Shibuya WWW X. Tickets for overseas shows and early access for the Tokyo concert are now available.
  • The tour’s title, combining “YOU” and “ZIZAI” (“freely”), reflects the theme of Slash-&-Burn: clearing the old to make way for new growth. Daoko invites fans to join her in embracing a fresh phase of creative freedom across Asia.

item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

When King of Seas was first announced, the gaming world was all about pirates. Sea of Thieves, released last year, is a multiplayer experience that started with very little content but now has dozens of things to do and over ten thousand concurrent players. At first, Sea of Thieves and King of Seas were bound to compete, but after a few delays, King of Seas ended up debuting almost a year later. If you ask us, King of Seas is a better pirate game... but that's just us. If you like sea chants, sinking enemy ships, and role-playing as the meanest pirate to ever sail the oceans, here's another game you need to try!

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

Honey’s Anime got the opportunity to try T-ARTS’s Gacha machines, and the process was very simple. First, exchange money for a special token directly at their booth, with prices starting at as low as five dollars per token. Next, browse through their large collection of Gacha machines, each featuring different toy collections from anime like Oshi No Ko, major IPs like Sanrio, or Japanese culture-inspired toys like convenience store snack models and cute Shiba Inu capsule toys. Celebrating its 60th anniversary in Japan in 2025, the Gacha area of the booth also offered visitors a hands-on experience with a free Gacha draw for those who shared their booth experience on social media.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

But more than the Gacha themselves, we were especially interested in their new blind box collection called “PERIHAPI!”, which they displayed onsite with adorable (and huge!) chibi figures featuring Vocaloid characters and cast members from the anime Haikyu!! We can’t wait for this collectible series to come to stores in the USA.

[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

The TOMY booth kept on giving, offering a huge collection of their movable model kits for adult hobbyists brought to us by T-SPARK, the unified brand for TOMY Company’s hobby products with various series. Starting strong with ZOIDS models, which impressed with their motorized series, and followed by TOYRISE’s Bang Bravern models for those who want more than just to collect, they want to build. Q VILLAGE was also there with its sleek line of deformed format vehicle models for Fast and the Furious and the legendary street-racing manga Initial D. The booth also featured a display of the SYNERGENEX crossover collection of Macross 7 × Transformers with Basara Prime model kits. And last but not least, the COLLEKAZARO brand showcased its My Hero Academia fully articulated collectible figures.

item.title: 더 강력하게 돌아온 ‘슈퍼 마리오 파티 잼버리 + 잼버리 TV’
ElenaBEY, a First-Year Blader, Wins the BEYBLADE X National Tournament Held in Los Angeles at Anime Expo and Earns a Spot at the World Championship in Japan!
item.content:encoded:
[sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]

[en]What You Need to Know: [/en][es]Lo que necesitas saber: [/es]

  • On July 5, 2025, TOMY Company, Ltd. held the Open Class (ages 13+) of the BEYBLADE X National Tournament for the BEYBLADE X series (the modern version of “bei-goma” spinning tops) at the BEYBLADE X booth during Anime Expo 2025, North America’s largest anime and manga convention.
  • This event was held to determine the top blader from the U.S. tournament who will advance to the BEYBLADE X WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP 2025*, scheduled for October in Japan, the birthplace of Beyblade. On the morning of the event, a crowd of eager participants far exceeding the number of tournament spots gathered at the booth, filling the venue with the passion and energy of US bladers even before the matches began.
  • Before a packed crowd, the closely contested tournament ended with ElenaBEY emerging as the winner. In the finals, she initially conceded a point to Yushua, who scored a “Survivor Finish,” but she quickly turned the tables by earning two points of her own. Yushua then caught up, tying the score and turning the match into a fierce, back-and-forth battle. In the end, ElenaBEY sealed her comeback victory with a stunning “Xtreme Finish” using an Attack-Type Beyblade. The crowd erupted in cheers at the dramatic conclusion, bringing the tournament to an exciting close that perfectly showcased the thrill of BEYBLADE X.
  • After securing her spot at the world championship, ElenaBEY was warmly congratulated by fellow competitors who had battled alongside her. She shared that she began playing Beyblade after a friend’s suggestion. Her victory in Los Angeles, the entertainment capital of the world, inspired many spectators who witnessed it.
  • With its new “Xtreme Dash” gimmick enabling ultra-acceleration, BEYBLADE X is the fastest in the brand’s history. It has captured the hearts of both players and spectators, gaining popularity worldwide as a form of “GEAR SPORTS.” Bladers from 20 regions*, are scheduled to compete in the upcoming World Championship, and qualifiers are underway worldwide. Keep an eye out for ElenaBEY as she takes the stage alongside other Bladers who have battled their way to the top. *In some countries, only one division is held, either the Regular Class (ages 6 to 12) or the Open Class (which is also open to adults).

    • Comments From the Top 3

    Winner: ElenaBEY: The friend who introduced me to Beyblade came to the venue today to cheer me on! I’m already excited to meet Bladers from around the world at the upcoming World Championship in Tokyo. Runner-up: Yushua I missed out on the victory, but my next step is to expand the Beyblade community. I feel that Beyblade is exciting enough to be enjoyed like a sport.” 3rd Place: TMS I came all the way from Texas to join this tournament. I was waiting for this moment for several years, and I’m just really happy to get to compete. I always plan my strategy, and I’m going to try out different styles that interest me.
    [sourceLink asin="" asin_jp="" cdj_product_id="" text="" url="" ]
    Alongside the BEYBLADE X National Tournament, the free-play area was set up at the venue during the event, attracting over 3,000 fans who casually enjoyed the Beyblade experience. To make it easier for beginners, Beyblades were available to borrow, and tutorials were offered, attracting a lively crowd of all ages, from children to adults.

    BEYBLADE X National Tournament (US Open Class)

    Date: Saturday, July 5, 2025 Time: 4:25 PM – 5:00 PM (Pacific Daylight Time) Location: Los Angeles Convention Center (ENTERTAINMENT HALL - E-25) Official Website: beyblade.com/worldchampionship2025 *Highlights from the tournament will be available to watch on the official BEYBLADE X YouTube channel at a later date.

    BEYBLADE X WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP 2025

    The first-ever world championship for the BEYBLADE X series. Winners from regional tournaments around the world will compete to become the top Blader, with the event also serving as a platform for international exchange. The championship will take place over two days, October 11 and 12, 2025, at the iconic Tokyo Tower in Japan. The tournament will be streamed live globally on the official BEYBLADE X YouTube channel “BEYTUBE” and on official regional YouTube channels, delivering the excitement of the event to viewers in real time.

    “BEYBLADE” battling tops, debuted in 1999, are a modernized version of traditional Japanese battling tops known as “bei-goma.” Over 520 million units have been shipped cumulatively in more than 80 countries and regions around the world (as of April 2023). Each series has created a craze in many countries across the world including Japan. The fourth generation, BEYBLADE X started in July 2023 in Japan.
